It is not possible to have a system that 'understands' something more complex and rich than the information that can be represented in it.

And yet, the Chinese Room argument fails. Its value is limited to exposing the need for complete meaning determination in cognitive systems.

The pseudo-time arrow of experience is encoded in the statistical structure of conditional independence found in the network of local binding of qualia. Time is in the causality-encoding v-shapes found in the recursive layering of qualia from moment to moment. #pseudotimearrow

Physical time is also encoded in the statistical structure of conditional independence, which is correlated (although not the same with) entropy. There are edge cases and outlier structures where time and entropy gradients go in different directions.
The difference between the physical time arrow and the pseudo-time arrow of experience is that global binding limits the domain for which phenomenal time applies to a finite patch of coherent energy.

By manipulating parameters such as local binding probability and qualia decay velocity (as with "tracers" and "interconnectivity" on psychedelics) one can modify time perception. Time reversal, moments of eternity, etc. are explained by unusual pseudo-time arrows.
"Yesterday I ate only french fries. Today I ate french fries and almond butter. That's a step in the right direction." - The French Fry guy https://t.co/lDse7RTfT8

At extremes of psychedelia, the pseudo-time arrow can dissolve on the face of pronounced qualia annealing. Just as you cannot find an arrow of entropy on a crystal lattice, you won't be able to find a pseudo-time arrow in an experience that has annealing completely.

Abolishing asphyxiation qualia might be easier than abolishing a virus. The Hedonistic Imperative could succeed before the eradication of disease is completed. At least in that case being ill won't be unpleasant, but merely inconvenient.

In the long-term, it WOULD be great if we:
1. abolish hand shaking
2. cancel all large crowd events like the Olympics and parades
3. develop fast testing methods and randomly test people everyday
4. engineer our physical social networks to be geometric rather than scale-free

The only human societies that survived past 2200 did all of those things (no hand shake, no Olympics, daily testing, and geometric vs. scale-free social network structures). In the 2000s it seemed excessive, but it now seems barbaric not to.

For the record: I've been saying since 2010 that we need things like this. Chances are COVID-19 will stay with us until we have universally adopted a much more strict code for human contact, movement, and testing. It and other viruses won't be abolished until the ~2200s... https://t.co/bQM7t4TYBn

Core arguments presented:

(1) Benzos can treat anxiety, insomnia, palpitations, seizures, hallucinations, etc. If you use them to treat *one* of these symptoms, the rebound will nonetheless involve *all* of them.

(2) Kindling - How long-term use leads to neural annealing of the "withdrawal neural patterns".
(3) Amnesia effects prevent you from remembering the good parts/only remembering the bad parts.
(4) Neurotoxicity from long-term benzo use makes it harder for your brain to heal.

(5) Arousal as a multiplier of consciousness: on benzos the "high" is low arousal and the withdrawal is high arousal (compared to stimulants where you at least will "sleep through the withdrawal").

(6) Tolerance still builds up even when you don't have a "psychoactive dose" in your body - meaning that the extremely long half-life of clonazepam and diazepam and their metabolites (50h+) entails that you still develop long-term tolerance even with weekly or biweekly use!

Equanimity practice as valence hacking:

Equanimity feels good and counter-balances negative feelings. Yet, to experience equanimity you need to embrace experiences independently of whether they feel good or not. Seems paradoxical? A recipe and its results are different things.

Knowing the truth about equanimity (i.e. that it is STILL done for the purpose of enhancing valence) can make equanimity practice harder. Sorry! But it's a useful challenge: you will now need to develop equanimity about the truth of equanimity!

cf. https://t.co/bcvHnqlCUX

Buddha was a hedonist through-and-through. Just a highly refined, consequentialist, causally-aware and pragmatic hedonist of the highest caliber.
As we develop equanimity technology, this will become more and more clear to people. We should embrace this!

The more “clean” and “free of dissonance” you go into a 5-MeO-DMT experience the better it will be. Not only the better it will feel, but also the more it will heal.

I recommend practicing a lot of metta, concentration, and equanimity meditation for weeks before the experience.

Also, if you are not a “purist”, a low-dose of phenibut (e.g. 300mg) 4-5 hours before the trip will prevent it from becoming an “anxiety trip”. Additionally, taking a shot of ginger juice 20-60 minutes before the trip will also prevent if from becoming a “purging trip”.

I know a lot of people believe that is good, but I disagree – it risks annealing a traumatic ill-state of the body. Anneal consonant and loving states instead 🙂

Even more esoterically, I would recommend having a vegan diet for a few days before the trip, doing acts of kindness, asking for forgiveness for one’s hurtful actions, and so on. Meditating on the seven factors of awakening before the trip will also be tremendously helpful.

As you come up, think of the love in your life.
Wish for the happiness and well-being of all sentient beings with absolutely no exceptions whatsoever.
Open up to universal love.
Love the universe, and let the universe love you back.
This is the recipe for a good #5-MeO-DMT trip.

Predictive coding is a piece of the puzzle for understanding consciousness. But many proponents believe it is THE explanation; a full, complete model.

This overconfidence can be modeled as increased precision in the coding of predictive coding as a full theory of consciousness.

There is a bit of circularity here, as in when someone says the Bible is true because God says so and God is real because the Bible says so.

Predictive coding explains why people are sometimes overconfident in delusional ideas. Thus you become overconfident in predictive coding.

Thus we can model overconfidence in predictive coding as a defense against becoming overconfident in ideas that lack enough rational justification. It is comfortable and desirable to live in a rational pocket of sanity that has an explanation for why every other pocket is insane.

Alas, a full theory of consciousness needs to satisfy more core and fundamental requirements than what predictive coding does at the moment. It needs to explain the ontological unity of experience, their causal properties, the qualia platte, and its very existence.

For a fuller discussion about what a scientific theory of consciousness needs to do to be successful, see:

https://t.co/1C3vkvg5Od

and

https://t.co/3BZKdKBDBj

Every network scientist, mathematician, epidemiologist, or polymath with whom I've shared the idea of "scale-specific network geometry" said they hadn't seen anything like it before.

Someday I'll write a python library to compute it on large networks.

https://t.co/ujY58cYYEY

You all should check it out. Of course if you'd like to take on the project of writing software to compute it, be my guest! Just make sure to cite the weird QC article in which it was introduced 😉

Here a video specifically on the idea: https://t.co/voADYYfIB4

The main application is: get networks to maximize a particular type of flow while also minimizing another particular type of flow.

Most articles and algorithms for network optimization focus only on one of these aspects. Ex. how cardiovascular geometry maximizes oxygen delivery.

But clearly you don't want to *only* maximize flow, since there are things you want to prevent propagating. E.g. I predict that the scale-specific network geometry of our organs simultaneously maximize nutrient flow and minimize tumor spread. It's a delicate balance!

In the case of pandemics, you want to create a "dimensional choke" at a given scale that prevents exponential growth, while also allowing efficient flow of good things like goods and services.

For the internet you want good ideas for spread and meme hazards to stall.

Compare with "Constructal Theory" which claims to explain all patterns in nature by merely focusing on flow maximization. It's missing the other half entirely.

https://t.co/JhjCG6fC5v

The definition here being "For a finite-size system to persist in time (to live), it must evolve in such a way that it provides easier access to the imposed (global) currents that flow through it."

But of course you need also to minimize flow of currents that "shake you apart".

Here's an example drawing illustrating the concept (found in the QC article linked at the top of the thread). Notice how it shows that tendency to imagine natural large networks as scale-free is just a special case.

The geometry (and spread function!) can vary with scale! https://t.co/T30CDQCQGo

At what age do you think you can learn the most about consciousness by exploring psychedelics? 

I don't mean "learn about yourself" or "learn about your culture" etc.

No. Rather:

Learn about the mind, consciousness, the nature of information processing in the brain and such.

IMO people who explore psychedelics at the dosages/frequencies capable of generating useful information tend to be in their 20s or younger. Yet, holistic intelligence peaks in one's 30s+. I think people in their 20s are not usually philosophically mature enough for this work.

Of course I'm a bit arrogant here 😅 MY philosophical insights in my 20s were truly novel, meaningful, and non-trivial. BUT I have to say that I am in fact strictly more advanced in my understanding now that I'm in my 30s. And I expect I won't hit my peak for a decade or more.

Notably, Steven Lehar said that when he tried LSD in his early youth he found it "fascinating and confusing". But when he tried it again in his 30s while doing a PhD in cognitive science THEN he was able to make sense of the state in a meaningful way. I doubt he's alone.

John Lilly tried it only in his late 40s, and then ketamine way later. I think that was also a good age for him, since he had amassed a huge reservoir of information: reward circuitry, interspecies communication, sensory deprivation, etc. 

Sadly he became delusional; overused.

The key reason why the qualia-space of scent is non-Euclidean is because scent is a rich, complex, *dynamic* experience.

The concentration of various aromachemicals form a map not unlike that of emergent patterns in Cellular Automata.

The "region of life" is highly sensitive. https://t.co/vkkFFhA6XF

Example: lots of boring and linear flavor molecules like limonene become "alive" when you add linalool. The precise concentration of both will lead to very different outcomes: dinosaurs, marine creatures, and hominids live right next to each other in parameter-space.

This is ultimately why aromatic fougères are so interesting! They all are "similar" in a way, but they exist in one of the most lively/sensitive regions of parameter-space where exotic monsters and plant-like life are just a few % of hedione and dihydromyrcenol from each other.

But were you to make a series of perfumes with "only" limonene, pinene, amyl acetate, and other linear non-synergistic aromachemicals, you'll see the "landscape is flat". As long as they don't catalyze interactions, you won't have "life".

Life in Samsara is, to a first approximation, adequately depicted by the movie "The Cube".

You don't know where you are; in a sense don't even know who you are. Don't know why you are here. People keep appearing. And escape requires skill, cooperation, dedication, & equanimity.

And yes, make the wrong turn and you will die in a creative way. Stay put and don't try to escape and you'll die in a boring way (like asphyxiation, thirst, or hunger).

Fun place, this Darwinian world.

Most people get distracted by the pretty colors, and confuse The Cube for a funhouse, until it's too late.

I asked if people knew what "powdery" meant on a survey, and most people didn't.

Look, it's definitely like the color red in Marry's Room.

If you haven't smelled it, you don't know what it is.

Below is a list of the most powdery scents I've ever encountered: https://t.co/ge8NUFYCmq

1) Violet: real essential oil, not cheap "fragrance oil" as those tend to emphasize the signature  beta-ionone sweetness rather than the powderyness

2) Iris: besides violet, this one is the second most powdery flower oil in my experience. Both are also flowery-sweet.

3) Virginian Cedarwood: of the woody scents, cedar is by far the most powdery in my experience. A distinct "drying" and pulverizing effect. Grounding at times.

4) Pear: about 50% of the e.o. and f.o. of pear I've smelled have powderyness. If they have it, it will be obvious.

5) Vanilla fragrance oil (e.g. the one from the brand Eternal Essences): about 25% of vanilla f.o. are powdery. Do you remember those signature car fresheners of the 90s with a chemically scented vanilla note? That's the one. Pure vanillin, however, isn't much powdery.

6) Angelica Root essential oil: this has clear powderyness, akin to (but much stronger than) the faint powderyness you'll find in Both dried ginseng and dried ginger.

7) Linalyl acetate: this is the only pure molecule I know that has a facet that smells exactly powdery.

In terms of perfumes - female powdery scents include:

8) Mitskouko: resinous version of powdery qualia

9) Samsara: vanilla/bergamot version of powderyness

And male perfumes:

10) Aramis: this is the incense version of powdery

11) Paco Rabanne (the original): this defies explanation and feels oxymoronic, but I'll make the educated guess that it's a powdery twist to amber

And

12) Azzaro: this is the only "powdery aromatic" I know

I'll finally add: I think that in it's highest expression, powdery scent qualia is an emergent *gestalt effect* that arises when several incompatible dry facets are balanced and refuse to blend. They sort of break each other apart and generate a dry mist as a fuzzy effect.

Like getting baby powder and clay to collide or rub against each other. They lift a cloud of very fine dust.
This is why, I reckon, there aren't clear powdery pure molecules. Linalyl acetate is a bit powdery, and iso-e super faintly so, but complex violet e.o. is super powdery.

Full p. zombies are impossible.

But scale-specific p. zombies are indeed possible.

If you can only examine the system from a certain point of view (restricted inputs, time/space scales) it can be indistinguishable from one that does use conscious computation.

Trivial example:

Lookup tables.

Yes, the Chinese Room need not be conscious. It can be literally implemented with a lookup table that anticipate the most likely queries.

Anything else? Yes, replace parts with lookup tables and those won't be conscious even by functionalist standards.

But if you are allowed the full range of scales and inputs to test the system, you can indeed discover it lacks appropriate internal representations. Meaning, it lacks internal states that encode the bare bones of the information that is being supposedly processed.

It's a similar issue as distinguishing a classical vs. quantum computer. You should be able to fake quantum computing with lookup tables *within some constraints*. But not in general. As you probe at more scales and higher input ranges, you'll notice runtime complexity issues.

With consciousness the key is that *phenomenal binding* is computationally significant. The holistic field behavior of state of c. is doing computationally useful legwork. I predict it has unique runtime complexity signatures.

Can be faked on some scales. But not all.

In particular, phenomenal binding gives rise to *weak downward causation*. 

Think about how you can use a soap bubble to compute a minimal surface. Same thing: every part of it is minimizing tension locally, but the film as a whole has a holistic emergent behavior.

You can simulate a soap bubble. But to do so you will need to sacrifice some computational benefits. It can look realistic if you slow down some processes in order to wait for the slower-than-expected behavior of the fake analogue part of the system. But this is detectable.

All of this to say: if scale-specific p. zombies are trivially possible and yet the AI and Phil of mind community can't figure this out (sorry!), we are posed to be bamboozled by AI pretty soon.

Many will fall for the trap of thinking they're interacting with sentient systems.🤦‍♂️

Intrigued? See the full explanation about how phenomenal binding works, here: https://t.co/2VCWMzcD0E

Under special conditions, such as using eye tracking or playing with psilocybin hallucinations, you can actually experience a given color "escape its container" and start to paint everything else around it.

It's crazy, but true. A ball's blue can bleed like a watercolor paint!

Same principle explains "neon spread", where the color is not sufficiently opposed by visible boundaries and so it bleeds into it's surrounding, and reinforces where such bleed-outs overlap. https://t.co/JjONd7gyq7

Colors escaping their container is much more likely under high-energy conditions. It's the recipe of Fire Kasina, which indeed can allow you to "paint your whole visual field" with a given color.

See Daniel Ingram's amazing meditation report: https://t.co/t2iU5gJwLf

All of these are excellent examples of holistic field behavior. Like a soap bubble, each part of its surface is trying to minimize its tension. The emergent holistic effect is that you arrive at a sphere, the equilibrium of forces.

Same with a typical stable visual scene.

This principle works across the board. And it's why we experience entire gestalts rather than merely mind dust. The entire visual field is in equilibrium, and at all levels, rather than only one part at a time.

Someone on the EA forum suggested cluster headache relief is like Make-a-Wish foundation. Namely, it's not EA-relevant because it only helps a few specific people affected. That it isn't high impact or a priority.

Here is why this is a gross equivocation: https://t.co/qcltDThN8l

Make-a-Wish spends an average of ~$10,000 per kid to fulfill their last wishes. 

Preventing a cluster headaches might cost as little as $5 per patient/year.

Namely, the cost of a DMT vapepen, which at scale wouldn't cost more than disposable a vapepen.

https://t.co/QiXJPPXdrR

According to someone I interviewed who suffers from both migraines and cluster headaches, of the disruption causes by the pain of a migraine is "like a little motorboat on the water", the pain of a cluster headache is like a "massive jet engine on the water".

An educated guess of the relative pain levels of migraines vs. cluster headaches is a factor of x100-1000. In terms of dolors/second.

More so, these are much more common than people realize. 1/1000 people suffer from them, and they're at a much greater risk of commiting suicide.

More so, the average number of headaches per patient is likely highly underestimated: headaches per patient per year follows a long tail distribution, with a median of ~70 1.5 hour headaches per year.

But the average of long tails needs large sample sizes to be estimated.

So the likely number of hours spent in the hell of cluster headaches is likely much higher than studies suggest (which usually only report the mean of a small sample size).

See: https://t.co/R6dvVlLRxs

So we are talking about a possible lower bound of ~100 hours of extreme hell prevented by $5 (in the long run, if the intervention is adopted).

Compared to, say, 10 hours of happiness costing $10,000, the value prop is very different than Make-a-Wish.

https://t.co/wHT1piJ0h8

My claim is that if we include something along the lines of a "hell-index" as a factor in our EA calculations, cluster headache relief will likely bubble up to close to the top of the cause prioritization.

See: https://t.co/VLcN7EsJfb
But as long as we only think in terms of QALYs & similar, this entire area of highly promising interventions will remain completely invisible.

Fun mathematical fact: any geometric construction you can do with a compass and a straightedge can be done with a compass alone. Sounds incredible but it's true.

Example: you can find the middle point between two points on the plane only with a compass. The how is surprising.

Remember posing that problem (find middle point between two points) to the Mexican Math Olympiad gold medalists back in the day. Only two of them figured out how to do it in the span of like an hour. So it's not as trivial as it sound. I think it took me like three hours, iirc.

It's called the Mohr–Mascheroni theorem.

To a large extent, the general computational power of the human mind (as opposed to e.g. a cat's mind) comes from our ability to instantiate an incredible pallette of subtle gradients of *moods*. Notice how to *think right* about a topic is equivalent to *finding the right mood*.

Moods play the role of providing evolutionary selection pressures for patterns of local binding.

A large fraction of the phenomenal character of a mood can be captured by it's consonance, dissonance, noise signature (CDNS).

In turn, if you want to "understand someone's brain" or make sense of "how they think", the main task for you to figure out is "what is their typical mood palette" and what's the "transition probability between such moods".

This has important implications for human alignment.

He who controls your mood, controls the evolutionary selection pressures of your patterns of qualia.

Memeplexes that restrict which moods are allowed, will in turn restrict what kind of qualia computing you're capable of.

Think about it when you feel your mind is "constricted".

The criticism against the idea that consciousness is a field is IMO pretty much isomorphic to the criticism Faraday, Maxwell, and the Maxwellians got when they tried to articulate electromagnetism in terms of field equations.

There were even "proofs" it could not be possible.

Some even made fun of the whole idea. Of course the counter-arguments were, well, begging the question: the proofs were based on the idea that a force applied in one direction could only ever come back in the opposite.

Linear action-at-a-distance made the notion that *curl* could have any effect absurd. H could force applied in this direction result in a different kind of force emerge *orthogonally to it*. Absurd! Silly!

But, mind you, the criticism was only valid *given* the implicit ontological assumptions.

Same with, e.g. arguing against consciousness being a field on the basis that classical physics tells us the world is made of atoms & forces.

Yet, the universe is in fact a gigantic field.

I'm convinced the *actual* reason behind the criticism is, well, to not look dumb in front of what you perceive to be the smart & well-informed thinkers in your reference class.

But once you dig into it, you'll realize they actually aren't as informed as you fist thought.

"I wouldn't be caught dead agreeing with one of those people who think it's a field..." 😆

Well, there is a great reward awaiting those who can endure being perceived as silly.

As people rise in prominence, they often start censoring themselves. You don't want to offend your supporters and those who give you power.

I promise that, no matter how recognized I become, I will never succumb to social pressure this way. I'll *always* say the following:

- We have a moral obligation to eradicate suffering.

- Factory farms and slaughter houses (i.e. death and suffering factories) ought to be closed.

- Ultimately our obligation extends to wild animals, too.

- A very big proportion, perhaps the bulk, of suffering is genetically driven. No amount of environmental interventions without genetic therapy will get rid of it.

- Suffering seems to follow a long-tail distribution. I'm not *too* concerned about the average person's suffering. The ethical priority is to save the top 1% who suffer from things like cluster headaches, CRPS, and fibromyalgia. Same for non-human animals.

- DMT instantiates states of consciousness with exotic pseudo-time arrows, as well as hyperbolic phenomenal space, and even (I kid you not) higher-dimensional phenomenal objects. I'm willing to defend these claims no matter how much social ridicule they may entail. They are true.

- Digital computers cannot be conscious because they lack the capacity to solve the binding problem.

- Expanding to other planets and galaxies would be deeply, deeply immoral *unless* we first figure out the way to become animated by information-sensitive gradients of bliss.

- It is in fact possible to directly probe the question "why does anything exist?" with Zero Ontology and 5-MeO-DMT. Very outlandish claim... But IMO very defensible.

- It is possible that the bulk of valences experiences aren't biological, but rather, located in cosmological objects like black holes, quasars, and the quantum vacuum. If so, then biological life may be just a tiny fraction of *what matters* in the universe. (Cont.)

This would entail that the "plot" of the universe has humans as a mere side show... Until we can do large scale cosmological engineering to enahnce the valence of the universe.

And that's that. 😋😉

Now... It's possible I could change my mind about these issues. But AFAIK they are true. It would be a shame if were to start self-censoring about the "weird stuff" when gaining recognition of a more official/academic kind.

Rest assured I won't.

When making a new perfume, it's always tempting to add a little bit of everything just for fun. Why not 0.01% of ambroxan? Or a dash of lavender? A pinch of honeydew melon?

I, too, used to have this temptation. It's fun! But it comes at a cost.

This is because the information content of a perfume is not only a function of what's in it, but also of what isn't in it!

If you merely keep adding things at random, you will slowly, but surely, converge towards Laurax (white noise scent). Be mindful of the "scent entropy"!

The perfume *not* having ambroxan is in fact part of its information content.

In fact, in many cases, you can make an interesting scent *by subtraction*.

E.g. take a rose accord and *remove* from it some elements. What's a rose without geraniol?

This, too, is scent innovation.

Some would say, for instance, "why not add citrus elements to Fearless?". The truth is: because then it'll lose its essence and distinctiveness. It might not play ball with classic Cologne ideas. But that's the point! It's what makes it unique and unforgettable.

Some possible _very human_ reasons why most intellectuals in the field don't talk about Jhanas:

1) Generic skepticism about self-report.

2) Envy - it's hard to admit _to oneself_ others are having so much healthy & wholesome fun as the fruit of their own efforts and you aren't.

3) Surface similarity with hard drugs/wireheading: it's hard to believe you can have so much pleasure without becoming addicted to it like a cocaine user.

4) Jealousy: if others know this is possible... They might work toward it and then won't be dependent on you for pleasure.

5) Top-down inference that it's impossible: our models say that pleasure and reinforcement go hand in hand. This rules jhanas out as a possibility. 

Cf. Don't let the theories dictate the facts!

https://t.co/zKWc9kPyaP

6) Unfounded association between a lot of pleasure and being 'dumb'. A lot of counter-signaling in the domain of intelligence and 'taste' comes down to showing others that you are not "easily amused, unlike simple people".

7) Lack of knowledge about the Log Scales of Valence!

7) (cont.) It's hard to believe, but the distribution of the *intensity* as well as *frequency* of intense please and pain seem to follow a long-tail distribution.

Yes, how much qualia/second you experience can range, not.just 10-20% but 10-20X (!).

This isn't generally known.

8) Intellectual embarrassment: if my model of the world has been missing something as big as this, what else might it be missing? Are my other models flawed and incomplete as well?

I’m an eliminativist about eliminativism.

What do I mean by this? I think that there is no real “thing” that corresponds to “eliminativism about consciousness”.

Rather, the people who claim to be eliminativists about consciousness are in fact an eclectic group of individuals who are confused in different ways and there is no fundamental essence that ties them together as a whole.

“Eliminativism” doesn’t carve nature at its joints. It’s a messy patchwork of fuzzy belief networks grounded in a variety of misunderstandings, misapprehensions, ignorance, social posturing, and introspection deficits of various sorts.

First of all, it is rather self-evident to anyone who isn't confused that consciousness is a “thing” that carves nature at its joints. Namely, “consciousness as a property” is that which color qualia, sound qualia, tactile qualia, etc. have in common.

These aspects of experience, an eliminativist might say, don’t share anything fundamental - they are a patchwork of algorithms that have no fundamental shared essence. But the fact that they can be bound together in a unified experience indicates otherwise.

All of these qualia varieties share the property of consciousness.

So why would someone claim that this is not the case? There are many reasons:

1. Straight up lack of insight about indirect realism. A lot of professed eliminativists talk in such a way that it becomes clear that they think they are perceiving the world directly, (cont.)

(cont.) and are thus confused about why anyone would need an extra mysterious “qualia” on top of “just the frequency of light we call red”.

2. Grifters of confusion: people who notice that others are confused about consciousness, and are happy to sell them a catch-all simple solution like “it doesn’t exist!” in order to gain academic positions, prestige, and book deals.

3. Curious people who have both high openness to experience *and* excessively high need for closure. Living with the tremendous mystery of consciousness is just too unsettling and therefore the temptation to sweep it under the rug wins out.

4. People who actually can’t even locate the referent for the very concept of qualia no matter how well you explain it and how hard they try.

They are not p-zombies, of course, but they may lack a particular “mental move” critical to be able to enter the conversation in any meaningful way.

5. People who simply think on the basis of (poor) arguments that ruling out quantum mechanical explanations about consciousness means that we must have a classical account of the sort where we have a universe fundamentally made of “atoms and forces”, (cont.)

(cont.) and who don’t realize that physics moved on from that view all the way back to the 19th century with the advent of *field theories* such as classical electromagnetism.

6. People demonstrating their tribal allegiance and playing signaling games by identifying with the fuzzy people-cluster of generic smart-sounding contrarian thinkers, but who haven’t even thought very much about the problem in and of itself.

7. People with radical introspection deficits involving a combination of derealization and depersonalization. People with actual binding disorders also fall in this category.

8. Smart introspective thinkers who are almost all the way there, but who still don’t “get” the binding problem and conclude that a radical solution like “consciousness does not exist” must be the only way out.

9. People who are so in denial about the immensity of suffering of the world that they would rather make themselves believe that it “truly doesn’t exist” than face reality.

10. Actual academic postmodernists / radical relativists who think there is no universally valid “here and now”.

11. People who do understand the reality of consciousness and how it challenges the standard scientific world-picture and gives rise to the hard problem but who simply use different terms for it (like sentience or self-awareness).

12. People who haven't thought all that much about the topic but see a large contingent of thinkers who nominally are all eliminativists and defer to them in order to not have to spend cognitive resources on the problem themselves (cf. disinformation cascades).

13. etc. etc. etc.
All in all, my claim is that despite its apparent self-evident “reality”, eliminativism is in fact not a “thing”. It’s not real, and it never has! People who claim otherwise are just confused.

When you realize that something isn’t in fact a real thing, it is perhaps worth moving on from it as a concept. It only causes further confusion to reify it!

I therefore want to make the bold suggestion that *eliminativism doesn’t exist*!
Positive valence to the people!

https://t.co/cGqr2ZgwOZ

Introspect on how the feeling of depth arises when you overlap these two images.

The fact that blending two 2D images to form a 2.5D representation is possible hints at something very profound: you can blend two images of ND to get an N+0.5D experience.

This can happen on DMT. https://t.co/qYyHprzHXJ

With recursive, iterative dissociation of your Pseudo-Time arrow and then stereoscopic blending of the resulting "perspectives" you can bootstrap much higher phenomenal dimensions than we're used to.

You can use two 2.5D worksheets as a source of parallax for higher dimensions.

Importantly, this isn't just experiencing higher dimensional objects. What's happening is far more profound (both literally & figuratively). You are instantiating higher dimensional *phenomenal spaces*. I.e. attention points w/ a distance function characteristic of higher D.

Another observation: when you use two 2D images to obtain a 2.5D worldsheet, you are sacrificing a lot of information for the sake of instantiating a higher dimension.

The y-axis becomes almost redundant.

A point's coordinates goes from (X1, Y1) & (X2, Y2) to (X, Y, Z). https://t.co/jtO9IKa1Dv

Meaning that each point lost a degree of freedom, but as a whole you gained a "virtual dimension".

In fact, you also lose a lot more information if we take into account the color of points. Info nearly halves, as now the two images need to be consistent with one another.

At the limit, when you experience phenomenal spaces of ~7D, there isn't much room for content left. Those experiences tend to be quite minimalistic. Something like a small pocket of information that is tessellated along 7 dimensions.

You'd be excused for believing in "infinite consciousness" right after having such an experience.

All/almost all of the information content is being sacrificed for the sake of increasing the dimensionality.
Note: this is rare. 4D spaces are common on DMT. 7D requires skill.

The 6th Jhana makes you feel afterwards that everything "has consciousness".

Vastness of Awareness causes an aftereffect where it feels as if everything is a "manifestation of awareness" or everything is the "interplay of awareness with itself".

You are infinite consciousness!

Let's make sure genes serve consciousness and not the other way around.

In reality there are no "points of view". What does exist is "topological pockets of view". Minimal surfaces w/ boundaries that aggregate information!

Realizing that consciousness follows the Huygens–Fresnel principle is perhaps one of the most substantial insights I've had since the Jhana retreat in November.

Essentially, when "waves of awareness" are coherent, they function as both a frame of reference and as a wavefront!

When you have clean standing wave patterns for awareness, the distinction between subject and object collapses. The waves are traveling on both directions at the same time! Source and destination are mixed up from the point of view of the wavefronts.

IMO/IME all oneness experiences involve standing wave patterns of awareness where it is impossible to tell "from within" what's the source and what's the destination. In a certain sense, they are the same thing (from the point of view of the standing wave!).

LSD oneness experiences tend to involve a "collapse of the dimensionality" of experience where "every point of view is the same".

DMT hyperdimensional experiences instead involve competing clusters of coherence where each provides its own frame of reference.

The belief that the Platonic world is beautiful - where all global minima of geometric optimization problems are richly resonant and tender to our perceptual faculties - is a delusion caused by confirmation bias. We amplify elegant proofs and structures. But it's really a mess!!! https://t.co/X5c65EtqMS

By all means DO focus on the beautiful.

But realize that beauty (in the sense of perceptual high valence - cf. ease of processing, cf. intrinsic consonance) is not the same as optimal. They're correlated only in so far as the set of symmetries we've got inbuilt to simplify sensory input click w/ those of the solution.

The Platonic World is a Mess.

We think we came here in order to fulfill the Parable of the Prodigal Child. That is, to witness the horror of disorder so we come back to our Father Plato begging for order.

But the Platonic World is itself horrible in weird ways. No thanks!

One important & novel insight presented in this brief video is the difference between two views on causality:

1) weak causality / deflationary: defined in terms of networks of conditional probability

2) strong causality / "contact": real underlying topological boundary-sharing https://t.co/olvgpdrO7i

I argue that Chalmers' organizational invariance conception of minds is ultimately grounded in (1). But this implicitly needs an omniscient interpreter that epiphenomenally decides when causality is happening in order to determine causal networks for minds. You need God.

On the other hand, for (2), you can actually arrive at non-epiphenomenal and non-omniscient ways to find true, objective, frame invariant, and causally significant boundaries that explain phenomenal binding networks.

We flip our conception of causality and its relationship to binding: 

(Weak) causality doesn't cause binding.

Rather, binding (contact and boundary-sharing) ontologically shift what building blocks you have for minds *and* it brings about (strong) causal effects.

In brief:

Causality doesn't cause binding.

Binding causes causality!

Also, this might reframe what is going on with, say, virtual particles that mediate forces.

In this case physics is tracking the probability of *contact* between solitons in fields. Distances are emergent out of this probability. But deep down there's still a *contact network*.

Consider what special relativity tells us: if you travel at the speed of light, you arrive instantly to your destination (from your point of view).

Perhaps when two particles interact via a photon, really what's going on is that they are *touching* each other. Contact!

Please make suggestions - Bliss Meditation? MDMA meditation?

Jhana meditation turns "no pain, no gain" on its head:

No bliss, no gain.

More specifically, "no bliss now, no further bliss later". So it also turns conventional wisdom about delaying pleasure today for a better tomorrow on its head:

More bliss today, more bliss tomorrow!

Note: "jhana practice" can actually be quite frustrating and boring for a while. And yet, having the attitude of "no pain, no gain" is precisely the opposite of what will allow you to make progress. Be gentle when meditation doesn't feel good. This *itself* is the practice.

One key issue with "waiting for the right time" to try psychedelics is that you may develop serious chronic pain or some other health condition and then not be able to have a good time when finally trying them.

I'm not encouraging anyone here; I've seen this story many times.

My sense is that 25 to 50 years old is the sweet spot. Not too early that you don't know what you're doing and won't get anything intellectually useful out of them... But also not too late they you'll have lots of body load to deal with and a lifetime of trauma to process.

This is different if you're a long-term meditator, are in excellent health, and have exceptionally good mental stamina. In that case trying them in your 70s is probably fine. But typically? No... Grandma who suffers from serious knee & hip pain probably shouldn't take psilocybin.
